causes: Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), 42 U.S.C. § 1997 et seq.
case_data.name: U.S. v. New York
case_data.summary:
On February 4, 1988, the United States Department of Justice Civil Rights Division notified the Governor of New York that it intended to investigate conditions at Creedmoor Psychiatric Center pursuant to authority granted by the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), 42 U.S.C. § 1997 et seq. Sometime that same year, the United States filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York charging that the State of New York, the Governor of New York, the New York State Office of Mental Health, and Creedmoor Psychiatric Center were obstructing the Creedmoor CRIPA investigation. Specifically, the United States claimed that the defendants refused to grant investigators access to Creedmoor unless the United States signed a proposed consent decree in United States v. State of New York, a lawsuit dealing with conditions at the Buffalo Psychiatric Center. The plaintiffs asked the court to enter an injunction to force New York to give the United States access to Creedmoor's facilities, staff, patients, and records and enter other equitable relief as appropriate.

We have no information on what occurred in this lawsuit after the Complaint was filed.
case_data.summary_short: The United States filed this suit seeking an injunction to give the United States access to Creedmoorís facilities, staff, patients, and records so that it could conduct an investigation of the facilities under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), 42 U.S.C. §1997. The Clearinghouse has no information on the disposition of the case.

COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE RELIEF
JURISDICTION
1.  This court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to
28 U.S.C. §1345.
2.  This action seeks to facilitate and enable the Attorney
General to conduct a lawful investigation authorized by the Civil
Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), 42 U.S.C. §1997.
t  3.  The United States of America, by and through the
Attorney General, has authority pursuant to 42 U.S.C. §1997, to
enforce and protect the civil rights of institutionalized
*
persons.
4.  Venue in this judicial district is proper pursuant to 28
U.S.C. §1391.

5.  The United states of America, by and through the
Attorney General, institutes this action to enjoin defendants
from obstructing a United States Department of Justice investiga-
tion of the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center being conducted pursuant
to CRIPA, and to direct defendants to provide access to agents of
the United States to the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center, and to its
patients, staff, and records for the purpose of conducting a
CRIPA investigation.
PARTIES
6.  Defendant STATE OF NEW YORK owns and operates the
Creedmoor Psychiatric Center which is a state residential
psychiatric facility.
7.  Defendant MARIO M. CUOMO is the Governor of New York,
and, in this capacity, heads the executive branch of the state
government.  He appoints the Commissioner of the New York Office
of Mental Health.
8.  Defendant OFFICE OF MENTAL HEALTH (OMH) is the state
agency responsible for the administration and operation of the
Creedmoor Psychiatric Center.
,  9.  Defendant RICHARD C. SURLES is the Commissioner of OMH,
t
and, in this capacity, has responsibility for the operation of
the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center.
10.  Defendant ALAN WEINSTOCK is the Executive Director of
the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center, and, in this capacity, is the
- 2 -

chief administrator of the facility and has responsibility for
supervising the operations of the psychiatric center.
11.  The individual Defendants identified in paragraphs 7,
9, and 10, above are officers of the executive branch of the
State of New York and are sued in their official capacities.
FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS
12.  The Creedmoor Psychiatric Center is an "institution"
within the meaning of 42 U.S.C. §1997(1)(B)(i).
13.  On February 4, 1988, pursuant to 42 U.S.C.
§1997b(a)(2), the Attorney General, through the Assistant
Attorney General for Civil Rights, notified the Governor of the
State of New York of the Department of Justice's intention to
initiate an investigation into conditions of confinement at the
Creedmoor Psychiatric Center.
14.  The United States instituted this CRIPA investigation
to determine if the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center was subjecting
its residents to egregious or flagrant conditions, pursuant to a
pattern or practice, which deprives them of federal
constitutional or statutory rights, resulting in grievous harm to
residents.  Any delay in the conduct and completion of this CRIPA
investigation may cause further grievous harm to patients
confined at the Creedmor.
15.  The United States is entitled to reasonable access to
facilities, records, and persons necessary for it to conduct and
complete investigations under CRIPA.
- 3 -

16.  Defendants have refused to grant the United States
access to the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center unless the United
States accepts a settlement proposal suggested by the Court in
United States of America v. State of New York et al.. (W.D. N.Y.
No. 88-138-C), a CRIPA lawsuit brought by the United States
regarding conditions at the Buffalo Psychiatric Center in
Buffalo, New York.
17.  The United States has rejected, as is its prerogative,
the Buffalo proposal.
18.  Defendants' refusal to grant reasonable access to
agents of the United States to the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center,
and its patients, staff, and records, obstructs a lawful federal
investigation authorized by the Attorney General pursuant to an
act of Congress and prevents the Attorney General from
determining whether the Creedmoor patients are being deprived of
their federal constitutional rights and are suffering grievous
harm as a result.
19.  The United States has no authority to seek a remedy at
law under CRIPA, and will suffer irreparable harm in the
protection of the rights of Creedmoor patients by this delay.
*  PRAYER FOR RELIEF
WHEREFORE, The United States prays this Court to:
1.  Enjoin defendants from denying or obstructing the access
of attorneys, employees, or agents of the United States
Department of Justice to the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center, its
patients, records, and facility staff;
_ 4 -

2.  Order defendants to provide to the United States
reasonable access to the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center, the
patients, records, and to facility staff;
3.  Order such further and other equitable relief as this
Court deems just and proper.
